text: hi my name is Rebecca and in today's
lesson I'm going to show you how to
sound more like a native speaker in
English and it's by using what we call
identical pairs now what are identical
pairs these are expressions where one
word is repeated twice and why do we do
that we do that in order to emphasize
what we're trying to say okay
let me give you an example of what we
mean so that we you can understand
exactly how to use these expressions so
here are 8 of them that I've written on
the board for you the first one is over
and over okay when we say that somebody
did something over and over or I had to
explain it to him over and over it means
I had to explain it to somebody
repeatedly again and again is another
expression which we'll see which also
means repeatedly now why don't we just
say I had to repeat I had to explain it
to him again you can say that and of
course everybody will understand you I
had to explain it to him again means I
had to explain it to him a second time
right but when we say I had to explain
it to him again and again it means that
we had to do it several times repeatedly
and you say that sometimes when you're a
little bit annoyed or when you want to
show a little bit more emotion about
what you're expressing okay let's look
at some of the other ones next one round
and round we went round and round this
means as you can probably imagine in
circles now what do you mean by saying
we went round and round it can be
physically that you were driving round
and round the area because you couldn't
find a certain address or it can mean
that you're going round and round in a
discussion and the discussion isn't
getting anywhere
it's not leading to any conclusion so it
can be physically or mentally robbed
that you're going round and round okay
next one he went on and on now on and on
means without stopping it means talking
at length the professor went on and on
lecturing us about the benefits of
finishing our education all right so
when we say that somebody went on and on
we are kind of saying that he talked too
long or she talked too long it went on
for a long time okay next one we had
already mentioned again and again it
means repeatedly the next one is little
by little okay gradually little by
little means that gradually you came to
understand something so for example you
could say I improve my English little by
little
or the plants grew little by little and
eventually I had a beautiful garden
so it means gradually alright next
expression all in all so what does that
mean all in all means that when you
consider everything or when you take
everything into account you come to some
conclusion so for example all in all I
think we should buy this house what does
that mean it means after considering all
of the different factors you believe
that you should buy that particular
house or sign that deal or so on okay
next example day after day what is that
one mean well day after day means every
day for a long time so for example day
after day he worked to support his
family okay he worked hard to support
his family and we say day after day
we're trying to show that it goes on and
on and it happens one day after the
other okay next one
word for word word for word means
exactly or precisely can you tell me
word-for-word what she said okay so you
want to know exactly what somebody said
or precisely what somebody said so when
we use this expression when we want to
do that we can say word-for-word okay so
here are eight identical pairs which you
can use and if you listen carefully now
you'll see that in many different
contexts English speakers do use these
identical pairs quite frequently so
listen for them and for you to start
using them the best way is try to find
some opportunity today to use one of
these expressions in writing or in
speaking alright and if you'd like to do
a quiz on this or many other aspects of
English please go to our website
wwlp.com thanks for watching
